bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lucy T. Howard, January 17, 1947

div1.p: Hench informs Howard that he has a large file of letters between her father and Reed and Carroll but is still searching for more, especially between Howard and Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lucy T. Howard, January 17, 1947
div1.opener:
January 17, 1947
Miss Lucy Howard
45 Pondfield Road, West
Bronxville, New York
My dear Miss Howard:
div1.p:
I wish often that I didn't have to spend time on my routine medical
work; it interferes so much with my hobby! I do apologize for my long delay in
returning to you the most interesting and useful data from and about your father.
I have at last had them all copied and herewith return the originals. Should
the latter ever be mislaid I will have a set on hand which would be available
for you.

On November 21, 1946, having been elected a new member of the Board,
I went to the Washington meeting of the Board of Managers of the Walter Reed
Memorial Association of which your father has so long been an active member.
The following were present, mostly old friends of your father: General Ireland,
General Kean, Colonel Siler, General Love, Admiral Stitt, Mr. Gilbert Grosvenor
(national geographic) and Mr. Hans Ireland. They wished to be remembered to
your father most cordially and regretted his absence. I took a few snapshots.
Let me send you a set.

I now have quite a file of letters between your father and Doctor
Reed or Doctor Carroll: I have about 40 such letters. There are still a few
missing, letters referred to in ones I have but still missing. They include
(1) a letter from Major Reed to Doctor Howard, dated November 11, 1900,
mentioned in one from Doctor Howard (Nov. 16, 1900) to Reed.
(2) a letter from Reed to Doctor Howard (Mar. 5, 1902), mentioned in your
father's letter of Mar. 7, 1902 to Reed.
(3) a letter from Carroll to Doctor Howard (Nov. 1, 1905), mentioned in
your father's letter of Nov. 13, 1905 to Carroll.

Mr. Herman Kahn, acting chief, Division of Agriculture Department of
the National Archives, has made a search for these missing letters and could
not find them; nor could he find any letters between Doctor Lazear and your
father.

So, if you are in an adventurous mood, Miss Howard, and see any more
letters sticking out of book-edges or used as book marks, I do hope your womanly
curiosity will wonder whether they include the missing items! I do hope they
turn up sometime and I have no doubt they will because your father admired
Reed so much I am sure he has saved them somewhere. Meanwhile I am very grateful
for your most courteous help.

You recall I discussed with your father what I believed to be a little
misstatement on page 48, of his 1930 book, “A History of Applied Entomology”
where he wrote: “They (Reed, Carroll, and Lazear) came to the entomological
offices in the Department of Agriculture to study mosquitoes before they went
to Cuba----”. I'm sure that is correct as far as Reed and Carroll are concerned
-2-
but I'm equally sure Lazear did not come with Reed. Lazear suddenly decided
in January, 1900 to enter the army, was promptly accepted and went to Cuba
February 2, 1900, not having met Reed or Carroll. He first met Reed in Cuba
in March, 1900 and Lazear never returned from Cuba. To be doubly certain of
my facts I showed this excerpt of your father's book to Generals Kean and Truby
and both agree with my conclusion. But this is just a little error, important
only to a perfectionist like myself who is trying to piece together every bit
of the story.

It is quite possible that Lazear did come alone or with Doctor Thayer
from Hopkins to visit your father in 1899, or early in 1900, when he was inter-
ested in mosquitoes at Johns Hopkins. This version appears on page 4 of his
“memorandum” (yellow paper) and is more correct than the statement in the 1930
book. After all the 1930 book was written 30 years after the events and it is
no wonder your father's timing of the various visits had become a little hazy
and mixed.

As to your father's comments on pages 469-470 to the effect that
Sternberg's instructions to Reed were of the most general nature and not
detailed, I have uncovered ample corroborating evidence and Generals Kean and
Truby likewise agree that your father was absolutely correct, the contrary
writings of General, and later Mrs. Sternberg notwithstanding.

In your recent letter you said you might be moving to Washington.
I do hope so; you have many friends there who ask of you. Have you any idea
when you may move?

Miss Howard, when I last visited you I said I would very much like to
have a photograph of your father as of about 1900 or thereabouts. I want to
publish it in my book. In your father's book he modestly reproduces the
photographs of scores of scientific colleagues, many less eminent than he,
but none of himself. You said you thought you could lay your hands on one and
would lend it to me. I do not need to keep it. I can have it copied (photo-
graphed) in the Photographic Department of the Mayo Clinic and return to you
the original safe and sound (registered mail). Indeed I would be glad to send
back extra copies as “interest” on the loan.

I would also like very much to consider reproducing in my book Reed's
letter about “Howard and Kerosene.” You were so kind to send me a photostat.
I'm delighted to have it but I fear it would not reproduce to the satisfaction
of publishers. I photostated some important letters of Reed and of Lazear
and finally had to photograph them. Sometime if you could have a local photographer
copy that letter and let me buy not only a print but the film I'd appreciate
it very much. Or if your father's trust in registered mail reaches the point
that he'd be willing to lend it to me I could have it photographed here (an
extra film for you if you wish).

I was especially interested in your father's “memorandum” (undated,
typed on yellow paper) modestly disclaiming certain credit given him. Does
your father, or do you, have any recollection of when it was written. I would
like to know.

Your father, when I visited him in May, stated he had a collection
of snapshots, et cetera, at Onteora. If in your house-cleaning or treasure-
-3-
hunting activities you come across them and find any of your father and
Doctors Reed, Lazear, or Carroll it would be most interesting to see them.

One more thing: in your father's letter of October 31, 1906 to
Doctor Kelly he speaks of a talk about Reed's work he gave at a dinner at
Graham Bell's which may have initiated the Reed Memorial. I have a letter
your father wrote Doctor Kelly on January 19, 1924 in which he again mentioned
“the speech I made at the Graham Bell dinner.” Does your father now recall
whether this was an extemporaneous speech or one written down and whether a
copy was ever published or might be found in his personal files?

I fear I have asked you again to do several more favors for me. I
can only say again how much I am indebted to you and restate my earnest desire
to set forth clearly your father's important advisory role in the Conquest of
Yellow Fever.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
